The following pathogenic facts explain five basic clinical and epidemiological concepts shared by respiratory viruses:
The incubation time is very short, from hours to 5 days.
There is abundant production of the virus at the portal of entry, which facilitates viral shedding and high infectivity.
Viral diffusion via mucosal proximity causes simultaneous and bilateral compromise of more than one segment of the respiratory airways and their annexes—for example, the paranasal sinuses and the middle ear.
The defense mechanisms in play—both innate and specifically acquired (immunoglobulin A)—are mainly of a local character.
Specific immunity is temporary and lasts only for some months (Table 28.4).
